questions.text: What characteristic electron microscopy finding is associated with Langerhans cell histiocytosis?
questions.solution:
Langerhans cell histiocytosis

  • Clonal neoplasm resembling Langerhans cells: characteristic grooved or folded nuclei, moderate cytoplasm amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm
  • Lots of associated eosinophils, histiocytes, and giant cells
  • No prominent nucleoli or significant atypia
  • IHC:- cells express s100, CCD1a, Langerin (CD207), and CD68
  • Molecular: MAPK pathway activation (e.g. BRAF V600E)
  • If single system → often impacts skull
  • If multisystem → can impact many bones and organs
  • Most common in kids
  • Prognosis depends on stage, but is generally good (and excellent in single system disease)
  • BIRBECK GRANULES are the classic EM finding of LCH. Additionally, the langerin protein has been localized to the Birbeck granules. Additionally, numerous filopodia can be seen on the surface of the cells.
  • Weibel-Palade bodies (choice A):- storage granules for von Willebrand factor and P-selectin found in cells with an endothelial differentiation
  • Rhomboid crystals (choice D):- typical EM finding of alveolar soft part sarcoma.

Key Takeaways: The characteristic electron microscopy finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is Birbeck granules. These are rod- or racket-shaped structures present in the cytoplasm of Langerhans cells. LCH is marked by clonal neoplasm resembling Langerhans cells with features such as grooved nuclei, eosinophilic cytoplasm, and the expression of markers like S100, CD1a, and Langerin (CD207). It can affect single or multisystem organs, with a generally good prognosis, especially in single-system cases.

questions.text: What is the classic neoplastic cell of a chordoma?
questions.solution:
CHORDOMA :-

  • Malignant.
  • Usually in the axial skeleton, equally distributed between skull base (esp. Clivus), vertebrae, and sacrum.
  • Large epithelioid cells with eosinophilic to clear cytoplasm separated into lobules by fibrous septae.
  • Some cells have bubbly "Physaliphorous" cytoplasm
  • Arranged in cords and nests embedded in abundant myxoid matrix or more cellular packets.
  • Variable pleomorphism and mitotic activity.
  • IHC: Expresses Brachyury and cytokeratin
  • Molecular: A subset of cases have Brachyury (TBXT), copy number variations
  • Intermediate aggressiveness, but can dedifferentiate
  • "Poorly differentiated chordoma:" Cohesive nests of epithelioid cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Scattered signet ring-like cells. Often rhabdoid areas. Loss of SMARCB1 (INI1) expression.
  • Poor prognosis.

Key Takeaways: The classic neoplastic cell of a chordoma is the physaliphorous cell, which has bubbly cytoplasm. Chordomas are malignant tumors commonly found in the axial skeleton, particularly at the skull base, vertebrae, and sacrum. These tumors express Brachyury and cytokeratin on immunohistochemistry.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the ER with complaints of right lower quadrant abdominal pain. A CT demonstrated an inflamed appendix. There was also a lesion in the right iliac crest, and plain films were performed, which showed a lobulated lesion with sharply-defined sclerotic scalloped border (shown below). The lesion was curetted and the biopsy is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CHONDROMYXOOID FIBROMA

  • Benign.
  • Occurs in many sites, but often long bones near the knee. Also seen in small bones of the hands and feet, pelvis, ribs, vertebrae, and skull base.
  • Lobulated lesion with sharp margins and zonal architecture.
  • Chondroid and stellate cells embedded in a chondroid to myxoid matrix in the centre of each lobule
  • Peripheral spindled cells and admixed giant cells.
  • Radiographically, it is sharply defined and often has a pronounced shell of surrounding reactive bone. It is usually located in the medullary portion of the bone.
  • IHC: Diffuse S100 positivity (like all cartilage)
  • Molecular: GRM1 fusions/upregulation

Key takeaways: The diagnosis is Chondromyxoid Fibroma, a benign bone tumor typically found in long bones and small bones like those in the hands, feet, and pelvis. It appears as a lobulated lesion with sharp margins and a chondroid to myxoid matrix. It is positive for S100 and may show GRM1 fusions.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presented with increase pain on walking. She reports that she has had a bump or knot just below her knee for several years that has only recently begun to hurt. A lesion was seen on X-ray, and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteochondroma

  • Benign bone tumors
  • The average age of the patient at onset → 10 years
  • Mostly tumor appears before the patient is 20 years old
  • Usually asymptomatic, but it may become symptomatic if the stalk fractures, an overlying bursa develops, or if the mass impinges on adjacent neurovascular structures.
  • The most common locations → metaphyses of the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and pelvis.
  • Cartilage cap with growth plate like architecture and an underlying stalk with medullary and cortical bone.
  • Continuous with medullary cavity and cortex of bone
  • No atypical mitoses
  • Molecular :- Bi-allelic inactivation of EXT1 or EXT2
  • Germline mutation in EXT1 are present in hereditary multiple osteochondroma syndrome

Key Takeaways: Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor common in young patients, often asymptomatic but can cause pain. It features a cartilage cap and stalk, typically located in the metaphyses of long bones. Genetic mutations in EXT1 or EXT2 are involved.

choices.text: Located in cortex of anterior Tibia
CK14+, CK19+, vimentin+, SlO0-, EGFR+, NSE-

questions.text: What is the WRONG about an adamantinoma from the following?
questions.solution:
Adamantinoma

  • Locally aggressive to Malignant.
  • Often youngish adult.
  • Located in cortex of anterior Tibia or Fibula
  • Biphasic with a variety of morphologic patterns with variable epithelial component within a bland osteofibrous component.
  • The basaloid pattern is the most common and consists of solid nests of basaloid cells with palisading at the periphery and sometimes a stellate configuration in the center. The tubular pattern simulates closely the appearance of a vascular neoplasm
  • Classic adamantinoma: obvious epithelial element in fibro-osseous stroma. Epithelium can be squamous, basaloid, tubular, or spindled. Malignant.
  • Osteofibrous dysplasia-like adamantinoma: Inconspicuous Epithelial cells (see clusters on CK IHC), primarily osteofibrous lesion. Locally aggressive.
  • Dedifferentiated adamantinoma: epithelial component progressed To high-grade sarcoma
  • Tendency to locally recur
  • IHC:- An adamantinoma lesion demonstrates mesenchymal and epithelial components. The epithelial components are positive for pankeratin; specifically, they are positive for CKl 4 and CK19, with a large portion also positive for CKS and CKl 7. Additionally the epithelial component is usually positive for EGFR. The cells are positive for vimentin, but negative for S100, NSE, and vascular markers. (Option D)

Key Takeaways: Adamantinoma is a locally aggressive tumor, typically found in the anterior cortex of the tibia. It has a biphasic morphology, with both epithelial and osteofibrous components. It tends to locally recur and is positive for CK14, CK19, EGFR, and vimentin, but negative for S100 and NSE.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl fell off her bike and complained of pain in her leg. Her leg was imaged, and while no fracture was seen, an eccentric, sharply circumscribed lytic lesion was found over distal tibia. The lesion was biopsied, and both the radiograph and a representative histological image are shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteoclastic giant cell rich tumors:-

  • Non ossifying fibroma
  • Aneurysmal bone cyst
  • Giant cell tumor of bone
  • Chondroblastoma

NON OSSIFYING FIBROMA (choice C)

  • Benign, generally self-limited.
  • Storiform proliferation of plump spindled cells with intermingled giant cells.
  • Scattered hemosiderophages and foamy macrophages.
  • Skeletally immature patients in cortex of metaphysis in
  • Long bones, often near knee.
  • Molecular: KRAS or FGFR1 mutations→ MAPK pathway Activation

ANEURYSMAL BONE CYST

  • Multiloculated blood-filled cystic spaces. (Choice A)

Key Takeaways: Nonossifying fibroma is a benign, self-limited tumor seen in skeletally immature patients, typically in the cortex of the metaphysis of long bones, especially near the knee. It shows storiform proliferation of spindled cells with intermingled giant cells, often with hemosiderophages. It may be confused with other benign lesions, such as aneurysmal bone cyst, but differs in its histology and location.

choices.text: It most often occurs in the metaphysis
It is more common in men
It has well-defined lytic lesions with sclerotic margins

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning giant cell tumor of bone is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Giant Cell Tumor of Bone

  • Locally aggressive with rare metastases (often to lung) (choice D)
  • F>M (choice B)
  • Proliferation of numerous (reactive) large osteoclasts together With a MONONUCLEAR neoplastic component without atypia.
  • Generally skeletally mature individuals, involving the epiphysis (choice A)
  • Multinucleated giant cells with Mononuclear stromal cells have oval nuclei with even chromatin and ill-defined cytoplasm. Often associated hemorrhage, hemosiderin, and macrophages. (Shown in the below image)
  • Molecular: 3 gene mutations, most commonly H3.3 G34W (chondroblastoma has similar mutation, but is usually in the Epiphysis of kids)
  • IHC: (+)H3.3 G34W, often p63,
  • Can be treated with the RANK ligand inhibitor Denosumab→Giant cells disappear→ bland spindled cells with new bone Deposition

Malignant Giant Cell Tumor of Bone:

  • Sarcomatous transformation of pre-existing Giant cell tumor. Can resemble any high-grade Sarcoma.
  • Often retained H3.3 mutation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Giant Cell Tumor of Bone: Locally aggressive, rare lung metastases.
  • Affects epiphysis in skeletally mature individuals, more common in females.
  • Appears as well-defined lytic lesion without sclerotic margins.
  • Histology: Osteoclast-like giant cells and stromal cells.
  • Treated with Denosumab.

questions.text: 6-year-old boy presents to his doctor with ongoing leg pain that has progressively worsened. His laboratory results demonstrate a mild normocytic normochromic anemia with an elevated white blood cell count. The lesion was imaged and biopsied. Representative histologic images are shown below. CD99 immunohistochemical marker was positive. What is the best diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ewing's Sarcoma

  • Malignant.
  • Most common in the diaphysis of long bones (but can be in any Bone and soft tissue).
  • On imaging causes a mulitlaminated periosteal reaction→"onion skinning"
  • Most common in children and young adults.
  • Small round blue cell morphology. Uniform. Stippled chromatin and scant clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm. Can form rosettes.
  • IHC: CD99 diffuse strong membranous staining (not specific though) NKX2-2 (much more specific). FLI1 and ERG in cases with corresponding Fusions. Occasional keratin expression.
  • Molecular: EWSR1 fusions, most commonly with FL1, sometimes with ERG, Or rarely other combinations.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ewing's Sarcoma: Malignant tumor in children/young adults, often in diaphysis of long bones.
  • Imaging: "Onion skin" periosteal reaction.
  • Histology: Small round blue cells, uniform with scant cytoplasm.
  • IHC: Strong CD99 membranous positivity, NKX2-2 (specific).
  • Molecular: EWSR1 fusions, commonly with FLI1 or ERG.

choices.text: In the active phase of the disease, osteoclasts tend to aggregate, forming the irregular scalloped appearance of the trabecula.
It is generally an inherited disease, with an autosomal dominant pattern.
Bowing deformities and fractures most often occur in weight-bearing bones.
The classical radiologic finding is a "cotton wool-like" appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Paget disease is FALSE?
questions.solution:
PAGET DISEASE

  • Localized disorder of bone remodelling characterized by focal areas of increased turnover with excess bone synthesis and resorption
  • Often localized to a single bone in elderly men.
  • Bowing deformities and fractures most often occur in weight-bearing bones.
  • Early → more resorptive; Late → more synthesis
  • Unusually large osteoclasts with increased nuclei and prominent nucleoli.
  • Prominent osteoblastic rimming
  • Paratrabecular marrow fibrosis
  • Unusually thick and thin bone trabeculae
  • Numerous irregular reversal cement lines and bone scalloping. MOSAIC PATTERN.
  • Etiology poorly understood
  • Increased risk of osteosarcoma
  • Only around 10% of Paget disease has a hereditary component. (Choice B)
  • 3 phases to Paget disease
    • earliest phase demonstrating increased osteoclastic activity. The
    • active phase of Paget disease demonstrates an increase in both osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity. During this phase, osteoclasts can form aggregates resulting in irregular scalloped trabeculae, while the osteoblasts results in new osteoid production.
  • The classic radiology findings is a "cotton-wool" appearance.

Key Takeaways: Paget disease is a localized bone remodelling disorder, commonly affecting elderly men, with increased turnover leading to both excessive resorption and synthesis. It is not primarily inherited (only ~10% hereditary). Weight-bearing bones are prone to bowing deformities and fractures, and radiologically, the "cotton-wool" appearance is classic. Histologically, it shows large osteoclasts, mosaic patterns, and scalloped trabeculae in active phases.

choices.text: Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals, blue parallel to polarized light
Monosodium urate crystals, blue parallel to polarized light
Calcium oxalate, yellow parallel to polarized light
Monosodium urate crystals, yellow parallel to polarized light

questions.text: Which of the following combinations are the correct crystal type and polarization pattern/colour associated with tophaceous gout?
questions.solution:
GOUT

  • Uric acid metabolic disorder→ hyperuricemia→ deposit monosodium urate crystals in joint fluid and tissues
  • Classically middle-aged males
  • Most common joint: 1st MTP, but can get anywhere
  • Uric acid dissolves in water during staining process (so often not seen well on H&E slides), but can be seen on fresh touch preps or unstained slides→"needle-shaped" yellow, negatively birefringent crystals. Joint fluid often neutrophil-rich.
    On H&E: See fluffy pink deposits with associated granulomatous
    inflammation and giant cells. Soft tissue deposits = "Tophi"

PSEUDOGOUT

  • Calcium Pyrophosphate Dihydrate (CPPD) deposits in cartilage and joint soft tissue
  • Appear as rhomboidal purple positively birefringent crystals.
  • On H&E: well-demarcated basophilic material with virtually no inflammatory response
  • Often associated with degenerative joint disease.
  • Often incidental finding in arthroplasty finding.

Key Takeaways: Tophaceous gout is caused by monosodium urate crystals, which are needle-shaped, yellow, and negatively birefringent under polarized light (yellow when parallel). Commonly affects the 1st MTP joint in middle-aged males. On H&E, crystals are often dissolved, leaving fluffy pink deposits with granulomatous inflammation and giant cells (tophi in soft tissue). Pseudogout involves CPPD crystals, which are rhomboidal, purple, and positively birefringent.
